citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Microbacterium humi sp. nov.
Microbacterium humi (hu′mi. L. gen. n. humi of earth, soil, of soil, the source of the type strain).
Cells are short rods, about 2–3 μm in length and 1–1.2 μm in width.
Cells are Gram-positive, oxidase-positive and catalase-positive, showing aerobic respiratory metabolism.
Good growth occurs after 3 days incubation on R2A agar and NA at 25–30 °C; colonies on NA are yellow.
The peptidoglycan is of type B2α with an interpeptide bridge d-Glu→Gly→d-Orn.
The quinone system is composed of the major components MK-11 and MK-10 and minor amounts of MK-12.
The polar lipid profile consists of diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol and an unknown glycolipid.
The predominant polyamines are spermidine and spermine.
Major fatty acids are anteiso-C15 : 0, iso-C16 : 0 and anteiso-C17 : 0.
Differential physiological characteristics are given in Table 1.
Many sugars and other compounds are utilized, including N-acetyl-d-glucosamine, α-melibiose and fumarate, but not salicin, d-adonitol or putrescine.
The type strain, CC-12309T (=DSM 21799T=CCM 7687T), was isolated from the stalk of the edible mushroom Agaricus blazei grown in the laboratory.
